Details:
What is COVID-19 / Coronavirus?

There are many types of human coronaviruses including some that commonly cause mild upper-respiratory tract illnesses. COVID-19 is a new disease, caused be a novel (or new) coronavirus that has not previously been seen in humans. On February 11, 2020 the World Health Organization announced an official name for the disease that is causing the 2019 novel coronavirus outbreak, first identified in Wuhan China. The new name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, \"CO\" stands for \"corona\",\"VI\" for \"virus,\" and \"D\" for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as \"2019 novel coronavirus\"¬ù or \"2019-nCo\".

View CDC information

Where it started

Like MERS and SARS, COVID-19 closely resembles coronaviruses found in bats but not humans. Scientists believe that the bat virus had a change in its genes that permitted it to spread to humans, possibly via an intermediate carrier (snakes) in an animal market in Wuhan, China. Early on, it is difficult to know the exact source of the virus, how well it spreads from person to person, and how severe the infection is. The virus can be transmitted from person to person via droplets that come from the nose or mouth when we cough or sneeze. Those droplets can directly enter the nose, mouth or eyes of a person standing close by, or they can be indirectly transmitted by hands and inanimate objects.

How COVID-19 Spreads

The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, especially those who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet). The virus spreads through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs. How easily a virus spreads from person-to-person can vary. Some viruses are highly contagious (spread easily), like measles, while other viruses do not spread as easily. Another factor is whether the spread is sustained, spreading continually without stopping.

People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic (the sickest). While some spread might be possible before people show symptoms, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Community spread seems to be happening in some geographic areas. ""Community Spread"" means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.

More details here from CDC."

Symptoms of coronavirus

Reported illnesses have ranged from mild symptoms to severe illness and death for confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases. The following symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure*: Fever, Cough, Shortness of breath. *This is based on what has been seen previously as the incubation period of MERS-CoV viruses.

View CDC information

Incubation/Exposure period

Symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure. This is based on what has been seen previously as the incubation period of MERS-CoV viruses.

View CDC information

Coronavirus vaccines are being researched

While a vaccine is not yet available, researchers around the world are working hard to find a vaccine and bring it to the market as quickly as possible.

Fight the stigma

Fear and anxiety about a disease can lead to social stigma toward people, places, or things.

Some groups of people who may be experiencing stigma because of COVID-19 include:

  • Persons of Asian descent
  • People who have traveled
  • Emergency responders or healthcare professionals

How to counter stigma around COVID-19:

  • Speak out against any negative statements directed towards a group of people.
  • Maintain privacy and confidentiality of anyone seeking healthcare or getting tested for COVID-19.
  • Raise awareness about COVID-19 without increasing fear.
  • Share accurate information about how the virus spreads.
  • Provide social and emotional support for people who are connected to the affected areas.

If you are showing symptoms?

You should restrict activities outside your home, except for getting medical care. Do not go to work, school, or public areas. Avoid using public transportation, ride-sharing, or taxis.

Separate yourself from others and animals in your house. As much as possible, you should stay in a specific room and away from other people in your home. Also, you should use a separate bathroom, if available.

If you have a medical appointment, call the healthcare provider and tell them that you have or may have COVID-19. This will help the healthcare provider?s office take steps to keep other people from getting infected or exposed.

Stock up at home

If you are self-quarantined, consider having the following supplies at your home:

  • Hand sanitizer
  • Soap
  • Detergent
  • Dry food
  • Bottled water
  • Rice
  • Proteins
  • Fruits
  • Toilet paper
  • Surface cleaner
  • Dry food

If you have children in your family, consider stocking up on the following items:

  • Milk
  • Snacks of choice
  • Simple board games

Quick guide to Self-Quarantine

Self-quarantine is when you feel fine, but you separate yourself from others because there?s a high chance you?ve been exposed to the disease.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that you self-quarantine if you have a medium or high risk of having recently contracted the coronavirus.

CDC has identified these two scenarios as high risk:

  • If you recently traveled back from China?s Hubei Province.
  • If you live with, or are intimate with, someone who has been diagnosed with coronavirus and you have taken no steps to protect yourself.

The medium risk scenarios are:

  • Recent travel to Iran, Italy, South Korea, or other regions with sustained community transmission.
  • Close contact with someone with a laboratory confirmed case of COVID-19.
  • Living with someone with confirmed COVID-19 and taking some precautions.

If you experienced these risks, experts recommend that you stay away from others for 14 days to see if any symptoms of the virus develop.

How to keep clean

The simplest steps to practice good hygiene for yourself and your household

  1. Don't touch your face.
  2. Clean your hands often. Check out the video below.
  3. Avoid close contact, especially with sick people.
  4. Practice social distancing.
  5. Cover your mouth when coughing.
  6. Throw away used tissues.
  7. Stock up on supplies.
  8. If using food or grocery delivery, leave a note at door to tell the driver to leave the delivery at the door.
  9. Clean and disinfect surfaces regularly.
  10. Stay home if you have any signs of sickness

What is social definition

It?s a common strategy for reducing the spread of disease. The closer the contact between people ? and the more people in a group ? the greater the risk of passing along viruses.

Try to keep at least 3 to 6 feet away (1-2 meters) away from others. Avoid handshakes and hugs ? use smiles and ?hellos? instead. If you prefer physical contact, use fist or elbow bumps.

Avoid group gatherings, especially in poorly ventilated spaces. Stay home when you have a compromised immune system; are pregnant; have a serious condition such as diabetes, heart disease or lung disease; or have a cough, fever, and/or difficulty breathing. People older than 60 are especially vulnerable to the COVID 19 virus.

Engaging your children at home during coronavirus school closure

Coronavirus has caused extended closures of schools. Having children at home might seem daunting. We have prepared a checklist of few items to help you to create a great experience for your children at your home.

  1. Create a daily schedule.

    2. it's important to have set hours for school, meals, chores and other daily activities. Your chilren are used to a set schedule in school. So, having a schedule will give them a feeling of normalcy.

  2. Provide a learning environment.
  3. Embrace the difference.
  4. Bribe them a little, if necessary.
  5. Make it fun.
  6. Take breaks.
  7. Give yourself credit.
